headline.main: ASTRONAUTS DEPLOY SATELLITE AND GET CALL FROM REAGAN

results.snippet: The Challenger astronauts successfully launched a communications- weather satellite for India early today and received a telephone call from President Reagan, who said the presence of a black in the crew was evidence that ''we are in an era of...
results.lead_paragraph: The Challenger astronauts successfully launched a communications- weather satellite for India early today and received a telephone call from President Reagan, who said the presence of a black in the crew was evidence that ''we are in an era of brotherhood here in our land.'' The black astronaut, Lieut. Col. Guion S. Bluford Jr. of the Air Force, directed the deployment of the Insat-1B satellite at 3:49 A.M. An attached rocket then boosted the 2,400-pound satellite toward its higher orbital position over the Indian Ocean, where Indian officials expect it to provide a major improvement in the nation's telecommunications network. After the satellite sprang free of the space shuttle's cargo bay, Colonel Bluford reported to Mission Control: ''The deployment was on time and the satellite looks good.'' Later in the morning, on the Challenger's 23d revolution of the earth, Mr. Reagan spoke to the five astronauts from his ranch near Santa Barbara, Calif. The spaceship was flying 184 miles over Hawaii at the time.

headline.main: SHUTTLE'S ROBOTIC ARM HOISTS DUMMY SPACECRAFT

results.snippet: uf813        CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 1 - The Challenger astronauts flexed the space shuttle's robotic arm today in a successful test of their ability to hoist heavy, unbalanced objects on future missions involving the release and retrieval of...
results.lead_paragraph: uf813 CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 1 - The Challenger astronauts flexed the space shuttle's robotic arm today in a successful test of their ability to hoist heavy, unbalanced objects on future missions involving the release and retrieval of satellites. But periodic malfunctions, particularly with computers at a ground tracking station, continued to plague the mission's test of a new spacecraft communications link. Project officials said extensive trouble-shooting and some alterations in the system would be needed before the new communitions channels, which are routed through an orbiting satellite, can support the next shuttle flight as planned. On the Challenger's third day in orbit, Lieut. Cmdr. Dale A. Gardner of the Navy spent more than five hours operating the shuttle's 50-foot-long mechanical arm. He practiced lifting a 7,460-pound dummy spacecraft, a hulk of aluminum and lead, and moving it about in the cargo bay.

headline.main: EXCERPTS FROM NEWS CONFERENCE WITH CREW OF CHALLENGER

results.snippet: Following are excerpts from a transcript of the news conference early yesterday conducted from orbit by the astronauts on the space shuttle Challenger, as recorded by The Associated Press:    Q. Captain Truly, you've completed about two-thirds of...
results.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from a transcript of the news conference early yesterday conducted from orbit by the astronauts on the space shuttle Challenger, as recorded by The Associated Press: Q. Captain Truly, you've completed about two-thirds of your flight now. What is your assessment of the mission accomplishments so far? CAPTAIN RICHARD H. TRULY: So far I would say that the flight has been extremely sucessful. We've had a great time watching the fireworks on the night launch, the C.F.E.S. operation and the Insat deploy and the word we've heard from Mission Control on Insat are that it's working very well. And the T.D.R.S. testing has gone very well. I'm very happy about it. How does it look down there? Q. It looks great so far. Colonel Bluford, President Reagan on Wednesday congratulated you for paving the way for other blacks in space. You didn't have a chance to respond then. What would you like to say about your flight, what is its significance as far as blacks are concerned?

headline.main: NEAR ITS END, SHUTTLE MISSION IS DECLARED SUCCESSFUL AND THE MOST TROUBLE-FREE EVER

results.snippet: As the mission of the space shuttle Challenger was drawing to a close, space agency officials said the flight not only accomplished all objectives but also was the most trouble- free orbital journey by American astronauts.   The astronauts' flight...
results.lead_paragraph: As the mission of the space shuttle Challenger was drawing to a close, space agency officials said the flight not only accomplished all objectives but also was the most trouble- free orbital journey by American astronauts. The astronauts' flight plan called for their six days in space to end with a landing here at 12:40 Monday morning, California time. They were to steer the huge winged spaceship to the first nighttime landing to demonstrate that, if necessary, the shuttles could return home at any hour. The five-member crew, which has been living a reversed day-night cycle this mission, awoke early this evening to begin storing gear and preparing for their descent from an orbit 139 miles out in space. That was to occur on the astronauts' 97th revolution of the earth since their nighttime launching early Tuesday at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida.

headline.main: COLUMBIA GOING BACK INTO SPACE IN NEXT MISSION WITH A CREW OF 6

results.snippet: The first space shuttle, the Columbia, is scheduled to return to service for the next flight in the American series, and the Challenger is getting a breather after three flights in five months.   The Columbia, which has been idle for a year of...
results.lead_paragraph: The first space shuttle, the Columbia, is scheduled to return to service for the next flight in the American series, and the Challenger is getting a breather after three flights in five months. The Columbia, which has been idle for a year of modifications after making the first five flights, is scheduled to lift off again Oct. 28, carrying the European Spacelab, a research craft. A crew of six, the shuttle's largest yet, will be aboard, including two scientists who are not astronauts, one from West Germany and the other from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

headline.main: BRIEFING

results.snippet: More Millionaires    The number of American millionaires appears to be rising,   according to the Internal Revenue Service. The agency is not certain of the precise number of people whose net worth is at least $1 milllon, nor of the reasons for the...

byline.original: By James F. Clarity and Warren Weaver Jr

results.lead_paragraph: More Millionaires The number of American millionaires appears to be rising, according to the Internal Revenue Service. The agency is not certain of the precise number of people whose net worth is at least $1 milllon, nor of the reasons for the concentrated affluence. But using such devices as the personal consumption expenditures implicit price deflator and the estate multiplier technique, the I.R.S. estimates that between 1976 and 1981 the number of millionaires rose to as many as 500,000 from about 180,000. These estimates and much more about how the national wealth is distributed are tucked away in the texts and tables of Treasury Department Publication 1136 (rev. 7-83), also known as the Statistics of Income Bulletin, sold by the Government Printing Office.

headline.main: 3D SPACE SHUTTLE BEING PREPARED AS WORKERS SERVICE CHALLENGER

results.snippet: As technicians serviced the space shuttle Challenger here after its six-day flight, workers at a nearby plant were putting the finishing touches on the third shuttle, the Discovery, which is set to be rolled out next month and to begin flying next...
results.lead_paragraph: As technicians serviced the space shuttle Challenger here after its six-day flight, workers at a nearby plant were putting the finishing touches on the third shuttle, the Discovery, which is set to be rolled out next month and to begin flying next year. With the Challenger and the Discovery both in operation, and the first shuttle, the Columbia, in reserve, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration plans 11 missions in 1984, as against four this year. The Rockwell International Corporation, the prime contractor, expects to roll out the Discovery from its hangar in Palmdale, Calif., on Oct. 1, the 25th anniversary of the space agency's formation.

headline.main: LOCKHEED TEAM GETS SHUTTLE JOB

results.snippet: A team of companies led by the Lockheed Corporation today won a contract potentially worth billions of dollars to provide launching and landing services for future shuttle flights.   The award was a major upset for a consortium led by the Rockwell...
results.lead_paragraph: A team of companies led by the Lockheed Corporation today won a contract potentially worth billions of dollars to provide launching and landing services for future shuttle flights. The award was a major upset for a consortium led by the Rockwell International Corporation. Rockwell was the principal builder of the shuttle and until now has been the lead contractor for servicing it. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced that it would award a three-year contract to the team headed by Lockheed Space Operations of Titusville, Fla., to perform shuttle services at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida and Vandenberg Air Force Base in California.

headline.main: Widow of Astronaut Is Dead

results.snippet: Patricia Finegan Davis, widow of Lieut. Col. Edward H. White 2d of the Air Force, the first American astronaut to walk in space, died in her home here Tuesday, a family spokesman said. Mrs. Davis, who was in her 50's and had undergone surgery to...
results.lead_paragraph: Patricia Finegan Davis, widow of Lieut. Col. Edward H. White 2d of the Air Force, the first American astronaut to walk in space, died in her home here Tuesday, a family spokesman said. Mrs. Davis, who was in her 50's and had undergone surgery to remove a tumor earlier this year, was widowed when Colonel White and two other astronauts were killed in a flash fire inside the Apollo 1 capsule in a test at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida on Jan. 27, 1967.

headline.main: THE NEW SEASON: TRENDS, EVENTS, ARTISTS

results.snippet: 1. Maurice Bejart    The European choreographer brings his controversial Ballet of the 20th Century to the City Center.   2. Lucinda Childs    The avant-garde dancer and choreographer will be part of the ''Next Wave'' festival at the Brooklyn...
results.lead_paragraph: 1. Maurice Bejart The European choreographer brings his controversial Ballet of the 20th Century to the City Center. 2. Lucinda Childs The avant-garde dancer and choreographer will be part of the ''Next Wave'' festival at the Brooklyn Academy in Music in the fall.

headline.main: MONDALE AND GLENN VYING FOR EARLY LEAD TOWARD 1984

results.snippet: With the start of a busy schedule of preliminary events for the 1984 Democratic Presidential campaign, former Vice President Walter F. Mondale and Senator John Glenn of Ohio are entering an intensified competition for the early lead in the...
results.lead_paragraph: With the start of a busy schedule of preliminary events for the 1984 Democratic Presidential campaign, former Vice President Walter F. Mondale and Senator John Glenn of Ohio are entering an intensified competition for the early lead in the six-candidate race. Over the next six weeks, Mr. Mondale hopes to demonstrate, by winning a series of straw polls and the endorsement of the largest labor organization, that he has a pre-emptive lead with support among influential Democrats. Mr. Glenn's autumn strategy calls for an effort to convert his celebrity as an astronaut into broad-based popular support that will negate Mr. Mondale's advantage among party leaders. And leaders of the other four campaigns are going to be searching for new or more vigorous strategies that will put their candidates within striking distance of Mr. Mondale and Mr. Glenn by the time the first Iowa caucuses, tentatively set for Feb. 27, begin the selection of convention delegates.

headline.main: SPACESUITS, NOT SWIMSUITS, FOR YOUTH AT SCIENCE CAMP

results.snippet: For Chad Stone, the toughest part was shedding the 25-pound spacesuit.   ''I felt like a butterfly trying to get out of a cocoon,'' the 12-year-old seventh grader said. After Chad and nine other children tried on the spacesuit, they turned to 10...
results.lead_paragraph: For Chad Stone, the toughest part was shedding the 25-pound spacesuit. ''I felt like a butterfly trying to get out of a cocoon,'' the 12-year-old seventh grader said. After Chad and nine other children tried on the spacesuit, they turned to 10 video screens to work on space mission programming. ''Pretty soon I want to be an astronaut or be involved in space,'' he said. ''I'm especially interested in computers, rocketry and how fuels are used in rockets. Science is neat.''

headline.main: TOPICAL ISSUES LEND SPECIAL DRAMA TO MOVIES

results.snippet: Filmmakers, perhaps taking their lead from the widely popular television docu- dramas of recent seasons, not to mention the kudos garnered by ''Gandhi'' last year, seem to be making a marked departure from the heroics and outright fantasy that have...
results.lead_paragraph: Filmmakers, perhaps taking their lead from the widely popular television docu- dramas of recent seasons, not to mention the kudos garnered by ''Gandhi'' last year, seem to be making a marked departure from the heroics and outright fantasy that have dominated movie screens of late, with the result that political issues figure unusually prominently in many upcoming films. In fact, the topics of many of this fall's major movies will be topical indeed, with dramas about an American photojournalist in Nicaragua, a woman lawyer in Israel who falls in love with a Palestinian, a band of anti-nuclear terrorists who hold a group of American officials hostage, a group of veterans who go back to Vietnam to rescue their buddies from a prison camp, and the death of a worker in a nuclear plant. These are hardly laughing matters, so it's just as well that the fall schedule also includes an unusual abundance of comic relief. Chief among the comedies are a Steve Martin movie with a screenplay by Neil Simon, and a remake of an Ernst Lubitsch classic, ''To Be or Not to Be,'' starring Anne Bancroft and Mel Brooks.

headline.main: Guest Observer; The Fondue Ticket P. C. VEY

results.snippet: The doorbell rang. I thought it might be the guy to fix the gutters or maybe the garbage disposal. ''Are you here to fix things?'' I asked the six men on my porch.   ''No,'' said one. ''We're politicians.'' And with that they swept inside faster...

byline.original: By William Geist; William Geist is a metropolitan reporter for The Times

results.lead_paragraph: The doorbell rang. I thought it might be the guy to fix the gutters or maybe the garbage disposal. ''Are you here to fix things?'' I asked the six men on my porch. ''No,'' said one. ''We're politicians.'' And with that they swept inside faster than a horde of Hoover salesmen and began kissing my baby girl and shaking hands with me and my wife and my son and the dog.

headline.main: IF THIS IS WASHINGTON, IT MUST BE 'HISPANIC WEEK'

results.snippet: In proclaiming this as Hispanic Heritage Week, President Reagan has cast forth a Republican dragnet for that important voting group and left few appeals untried from what lately might be termed his Casa Blanca command post.   The President, beaming...
results.lead_paragraph: In proclaiming this as Hispanic Heritage Week, President Reagan has cast forth a Republican dragnet for that important voting group and left few appeals untried from what lately might be termed his Casa Blanca command post. The President, beaming under ''Viva Reagan'' banners, offered a few hesitant words of Spanish Wednesday night at the party's largest fund-raising dinner ever with by Hispanic supporters as hosts, and he hailed the group as preferring opportunity over ''welfare or handouts.'' Across the Potomac, a niche in the Pentagon's corridor of war heroes had been propitiously devoted to Hispanic soldiers. And down at the Department of Health and Human Services the first American Hispanic astronaut, Franklin Ramon Chang Diaz, was on hand for one of the half-dozen Hispanic-oriented ceremonies the Administration staged this week.

headline.main: PLAYING THE PRESIDENTIAL SLOTS

results.snippet: ATLANTIC CITY GAMBLING was not the only game in town here last week. Politics in some of its manifestations was played with enthusiasm from the gambling casinos and the Boardwalk to City Hall.   There were two beauty contests - one to pick Miss...
results.lead_paragraph: ATLANTIC CITY GAMBLING was not the only game in town here last week. Politics in some of its manifestations was played with enthusiasm from the gambling casinos and the Boardwalk to City Hall. There were two beauty contests - one to pick Miss America and the other to select the state Democratic Party's current choice for President. However, Mayor Michael J. Matthews's interest in these two events was distracted by a movement aimed at forcing his recall and a new election for Mayor in November.

headline.main: RUSH TO CLIMB ARARAT GIVES A TOWN A LIFT

results.snippet: Townspeople here say they cannot recall any comparable rush to climb Mount Ararat, that great volcanic cone that dominates the frontiers of eastern Turkey, Soviet Armenia and Iran.   This year the Turkish authorities eased restrictions, and...
results.lead_paragraph: Townspeople here say they cannot recall any comparable rush to climb Mount Ararat, that great volcanic cone that dominates the frontiers of eastern Turkey, Soviet Armenia and Iran. This year the Turkish authorities eased restrictions, and climbing permits were given to a score of groups from the United States, France, West Germany and Japan as well as Turkey. Most foreign visitors to Dogubayazit, the main base for Ararat climbers, were seeking some trace of Noah's ark, which according to tradition came to rest somewhere on the slopes of the Ararat massif after the Great Flood. But there were also scientists, publicists, alpinists and adventuresome youths among those who flocked here this season to climb Mount Ararat, whose peak is 16,945 feet above sea level. All this activity has greatly helped tourism in the area, which has been on the decline since Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini came to power in neighboring Iran in 1979.

headline.main: PAPERBACK TALK

results.snippet: Strength Through Series    Erroll McDonald had thought it through. Books by foreign authors that he and others edited for Random House would sell better, he believed, if they were incorporated in a series under the firm's Vintage paperback imprint -...
results.lead_paragraph: Strength Through Series Erroll McDonald had thought it through. Books by foreign authors that he and others edited for Random House would sell better, he believed, if they were incorporated in a series under the firm's Vintage paperback imprint - partly because people who like one book are apt to try others with the same brand name and partly because booksellers, who realize the benefits of brand-name loyalty, are likely to get behind books that, as a group, can command promotional resources while they are unlikely to support any single nonblockbuster title on a publisher's list. In January, Mr. McDonald wrote a proposal for a new series. This fall it is making its debut. ''Aventura: The Vintage Library of Contemporary World Literature,'' which includes originals and reprints, uses a distinctive cover design: Slender rules box off the author's name, the book's title, contemporary artwork in color and words of praise from critics. At bottom right is a calligraphic capital A, for Aventura; the whole name is spelled out on the spine and back cover beginning with the same capital.

headline.main: REAGAN'S CAMPAIGN ADVISERS SAY HE WOULD FACE TOUGH RACE IN '84

results.snippet: A month before the planned formation of a committee to re-elect President Reagan, his advisers agree that if he decides to run he will face serious political problems winning a second term next year.    In interviews, the advisers said they were...

byline.original: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: A month before the planned formation of a committee to re-elect President Reagan, his advisers agree that if he decides to run he will face serious political problems winning a second term next year. In interviews, the advisers said they were troubled that the political coalition that elected Mr. Reagan in a landslide in 1980 had greatly atrophied. They said that despite the improvement in the President's popularity since last year, they feared he was not getting enough credit for recent improvements in the economy. The advisers said they believed instinctively that Mr. Reagan would win if he decided to seek re-election, but that he had his work cut out for him. ''We can proceed safely only on one assumption - it's going to be a tough race,'' said Senator Paul Laxalt of Nevada, general chairman of the Republican Party and the man who is expected to become chairman of Mr. Reagan's presumed re-election drive.

headline.main: POLITICAL AIDES URGE REAGAN TO BACK SPACE STATION

results.snippet: President Reagan is reported to be under pressure from his political strategists to endorse a major new space endeavor, the orbiting space station, as a tactical move against Senator John Glenn, the former astronaut who could be Mr. Reagan's...
results.lead_paragraph: President Reagan is reported to be under pressure from his political strategists to endorse a major new space endeavor, the orbiting space station, as a tactical move against Senator John Glenn, the former astronaut who could be Mr. Reagan's Democratic opponent in the next election. Administration officials say the President is being encouraged to announce the new multibillion-dollar project soon and in some dramatic fashion that, in tone and spirit, would be reminiscent of President Kennedy's dramatic call in 1961 to send men to the moon. In this way, according to some White House thinking, the President might neutralize Senator Glenn's ''hero image'' and demonstrate a commitment to maintaining American leadership in space technology. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has lobbied vigorously in recent months to win support for the space station as ''the next logical step'' in the nation's space program.

headline.main: FOR GLENN, 'THE RIGHT STUFF' SEEMS TO BE RIGHT

results.snippet: Senator John Glenn, like almost everyone else involved in the Democratic Presidential race, has been wondering what impact the new movie ''The Right Stuff'' might have on his campaign.   ''If it's a good movie and I'm portrayed well, I don't know...
results.lead_paragraph: Senator John Glenn, like almost everyone else involved in the Democratic Presidential race, has been wondering what impact the new movie ''The Right Stuff'' might have on his campaign. ''If it's a good movie and I'm portrayed well, I don't know whether it has any impact or whether people just look at it as another entertaining movie,'' said the Senator, who has not yet seen the film. ''And if I'm portrayed badly, the same way, I don't have any idea what impact it will have.'' In any event, Senator Glenn added, ''there's never been a case where a movie like this came out right in the middle of an election period.'' That last remark, as it turns out, is an understatement. As the 193-minute film had its initial private screenings this week, it was clear that no Presidential candidacy has ever had a send-off quite like that afforded Mr. Glenn by this movie.

headline.main: 2 WOMEN SELECTED BY NASA FOR SPACE SHUTTLE MISSIONS

results.snippet: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today assigned two female astronauts, both physicians, to space shuttle missions planned in June and August next year.   The astronauts, Dr. Rhea Seddon, 35 years old, of Murfreesboro, Tenn., and...
results.lead_paragraph: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today assigned two female astronauts, both physicians, to space shuttle missions planned in June and August next year. The astronauts, Dr. Rhea Seddon, 35 years old, of Murfreesboro, Tenn., and Dr. Anna L. Fisher, 33, of San Pedro, Calif., are the third and fourth women selected to fly on the shuttle. Last June Sally K. Ride became the first American woman to take part in a space shuttle mission. Another astronaut, Judith A. Resnick, is assigned to a flight next April.

headline.main: No Headline

results.snippet: Speaking in the state where labor hopes to unite behind Walter F. Mondale's Presidential candidacy, Senator John Glenn today criticized labor's involvement in the Democratic campaign.   The Ohio Senator said he found it ''hard to accept'' that...

byline.original: By GLENN CRITICIZES LABOR ON ITS ROLE By FRANK LYNN

results.lead_paragraph: Speaking in the state where labor hopes to unite behind Walter F. Mondale's Presidential candidacy, Senator John Glenn today criticized labor's involvement in the Democratic campaign. The Ohio Senator said he found it ''hard to accept'' that labor would inject $10 million to $20 million nationally into a contest of ''Democrats fighting Democrats.'' ''Why don't we keep our eye on what we're supposed to be doing - getting Reagan out of there?'' he said in an interview en route here for the fifth of seven Democratic Presidential forums sponsored by the New York State Democratic Committee.
